Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES: Staying in STEM: Examining communal goal congruity processes in the retention of women

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The proposed program of research examines the unique contributions of communal goals -- that is, working with or helping others -- to women's decisions to persist in STEM majors. The primary goal is to extend the goal congruity perspective, both conceptually and empirically, to investigate retention of women in STEM. Communal goal processes are studied as both a challenge and a solution to the problem of the paucity of women in STEM fields. The proposed research program examines (1) the nature and extent of goal incongruity for female STEM majors, compared to other majors; (2) the motivational and social consequences of goal incongruity; and (3) the behavioral, social, and cognitive strategies that individuals can adopt to reduce goal incongruity. The major research questions are investigated through a multi-method approach. First, narrative analysis provides in-depth knowledge about female STEM majors' experiences with communal goal incongruity. Second, a longitudinal survey documents the extent and consequences of goal incongruity, as well as self-reported strategies to reduce goal incongruity. Third, several experimental studies investigate the causal effects of goal incongruity and the implementation of conscious and non-conscious strategies to reduce goal incongruity. The research strategy will be to recruit STEM majors to document the nature and extent of goal incongruity, and then to elaborate on causal processes in the lab by directly manipulating the experience of goal incongruity.

Broader Impacts: These studies offer the potential to add a critically important but understudied perspective on how and why women choose or do not choose to pursue STEM careers. Especially important is that the focus on communal goal processes highlights a new opportunity for change. If communal affordances are malleable, experiences in the college years offer potential to improve choice of and retention in these careers. In particular, these studies focus on documenting the strategies that might increase communal goal congruity, which then might be implemented not only by individuals but also by organizational units. The overarching goal of this research is to expand career possibilities for women and raise awareness of the many ways in which scientific careers relate to communal values.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When students see STEM fields as providing opportunities to work with or help others, they show greater interest in pursuing these pathways. Even people who are highly qualified for STEM careers select out of these pathways if they think that STEM fields will not give them opportunities to fulfill their valued goals. In particular, STEM fields are perceived as unlikely to provide opportunities for communal goals, such as helping other or working with others. We examined how opportunities to fulfill communal goals can foster persistence in STEM. Because communality is central to the female gender role, women and girls may particularly be attracted to STEM contexts that can integrate communal activity. We sought to understand whether students in STEM experience communal goal incongruity and what the consequences of goal incongruity are. Most important, we investigated what individuals and institutions can do to provide communal opportunities in STEM.

One important pattern that emerged is that both women and men responded positively to highlighting communal opportunities in STEM. Although women on average report greater valuing of communality, both men and women respond positively when communal opportunities are highlighted in a STEM context. Sometimes women weigh these communal opportunities more, but overall, both male and female students benefit when STEM contexts include opportunities to work with or help other people. Highlighting communal opportunities in STEM is thus a way to include communally-oriented individuals from a range of groups, without deterring less communally-oriented individuals.

When STEM contexts are seen as providing communal opportunities, people anticipate greater belonging both in that specific context and in the career tracks of math and science. An important point is that both male and female STEM professionals can highlight communal opportunities in STEM and provide this signal of belonging. In other words, even fields that do not yet have diverse representation can cue a sense of belonging in underrepresented groups: Knowing you are around others who share your values or pursue similar goals is also a cue to belonging.

Although stereotypes of STEM usually focus on a lack of communal opportunity, people see prosocial aspects of STEM work when they consider the broader goals of STEM. They then see a science career as integrating more communal purpose, and they are more positive toward pursuing a science career themselves. 

Across multiple studies, students’ own experiences with communal activities in science or math classes predicted their beliefs about the goal opportunities in STEM careers. These differential communal experiences, which lead to different beliefs about whether STEM affords communal goals, partly explain individual and cultural differences in STEM interest. Highlighting collaborative or prosocial aspects of science is a lever that can be implemented by STEM faculty and teachers, and holds potential to open the doors of STEM to a broader swath of the population. Preservice science teachers positively evaluate communally-oriented science lessons in terms of engaging students.

Overall, our research found several benefits of integrating communal opportunities in STEM: Students report more belonging and greater interest in STEM pathways. Individuals and institutions can integrate communal opportunities through both cognitive and behavioral mechanisms.
